nodes.text:
72% of black people *don't* support defunding police (Ipsos/USA Today).

81% want police in their area to remain the same or increase (Gallup).

How might these attitudes relate to violent crime, which falls most heavily on non-whites? (eg, 95% of NYC murder victims = not white). https://t.co/3ODvJKUSCa

@FreeBlckThought I’m interested to know where specifically in these cites do they go to administer these surveys? I often ask people or organizations I talk to in some of these cites to include my own and they have no idea what I’m talking about nor have I ever received anything such as this
@FreeBlckThought It’s appalling how prevalent misinformation is on your account. This is in the exact same article you cited btw. https://t.co/uz2mHLPFX7
@FreeBlckThought + Black Americans do not think as a unit. That is true, but to simplify that diverse thought in a way palatable to white interests is entirely disingenuous. https://t.co/05SS4XGGjN

@FreeBlckThought It doesn’t fit the narrative. The myopic view feeds lots of ignorance and is effective in riling up rage that is used as a tool. There are issues with police brutality but it’s not as great as the narrative says. It sure is feeding fear and violence, though.

@FreeBlckThought If one seeks to aid the victims of crime one must first address who it is committing those crimes in the first place.\nIt’s interesting you completely ignored that vital piece of information.

@arthurwatkins Yes, the political elites sold us a story in which all black people wanted the police defunded and kicked out of the neighborhood. Black views of police are complicated—they often *are* highly critical of policing—but they don't subscribe to the elite leftwing consensus.
@FreeBlckThought @arthurwatkins https://t.co/0zGmFGbO14

@lattes3000 8/\n\n...traffic enforcement, all bicycle and foot patrols, and community resource teams that protect specific neighborhoods,” saw 15 killings this January as opposed to 1 killing in January of the previous year. In 2020, across the country, “murder rates jumped more than 30%...

@lattes3000 7/\n\n...shootings alone in Minneapolis are up 250% compared to this time last year.[91] In this, Minneapolis participates in a nationwide trend. Oakland, California, where defunding has caused the disbanding of “several police units, including the homeless detail,...

@lattes3000 6/\n\n...in the wake of George Floyd’s death, to defund its police, first in July of 2020, and again in December. Not surprisingly, officers quit in droves, as they have done across America, and total violent crime skyrocketed by 21%. As of this writing...

@lattes3000 5/\n\nThe police abolition/defund movement was initiated by the Twin Cities-based Black Visions Collective, which has been duly celebrated by the New York Times for its efforts. But Minneapolis has paid the price for its citizens’ activism. The city moved quickly...

@lattes3000 4/\n\nAnimal lovers everywhere, take note: the LAPD’s cuts mean that it is also disbanding its Animal Cruelty Task Force. And if you celebrated when Harvey Weinstein got busted, you should know they’re disbanding the Sexual Assault Special Section that investigated him, too.

@lattes3000 3/\n\n...the Robbery Homicide Division, and others. It will also completely disband the following divisions and programs: Mission Area Safer Cities Initiative, Homeless Outreach and Proactive Engagement (HOPE), Burglary Special Section, and others.

@lattes3000 2/\n\n As a result of the $150 million in cuts Los Angeles made to the LAPD’s budget, the department announced it will downsize a variety of divisions and details, including the Hollywood Entertainment Detail (HED), the Pacific Area Beach Detail, the University Park Task Force,...
